Even if you were to send reach, kb and speed values, you could just edit the code and set reach to 3.

Plus the server already knows these values.

If they know these values, then why don't they just ban when over a value?
Because of lag, these values can be skewed, speed values especially, and if you were to ban if over those values, anyone who lags will get banned.

And Minecraft can't detect if you've changed those values, as because Minecraft is so moddable, any countermeasures can easily just be removed.
This way, servers wont need an anticheat and we would not need a client side anticheat either. Server could just ban people since they know their reach value when they join.

Interesting, what is meant by "edit your world"?

Do you mean like gamemode and gamerules? or maybe something like the MCedit world editor?

I think you're talking about a console edition of Minecraft, such as wii u edition or xbox one edition etc., the point is those versions of Minecraft still have minigames but they are not updated as they are incredibly old, try getting the newest version of Minecraft, bedrock edition, or even Java edition, it removes minigames and adds servers which can be blocked with privacy or parental controls.

What will the cost of the modpack be? Every add-on author would have to be paid, or consent to sell their add-on in a reduced price but only for that modpack.

Option A would make the add-on packs to be expensive and likey require the cost of multiple add-ones. What happens when a add-on author takes their add-on off and changes the price, how does that affect the add-on pack. Likely the add-on pack is dislisted for the first and have to increase price for the second.


Option B would pretty much limit the ability to turn a specifc add-on off, because it all has to be a package deal. As you wouldn't be able to get an add-on pack just to get two or 3 add-ons on a discount.


This would be a technical and legal headache to make and maintan.
Mods should be free!!!!!!! Right now okay mojang.

I think completely banning fees for mods is extreme.

    The rich gameplay in my world lies in the diversity of mods. However, mods are divided into two types: one is to add to the original gameplay, and the other is an independent gameplay. For example, Lucky Cube adds fun to the original game, but it relies on the original game. The furniture mod in the creation mode should be independent, and even a complete furniture mod can be independent of the game without relying on the original items. It transforms my world from adventure survival to a new decoration game. Many developers need some financial support, otherwise they cannot continue to update. I think some mods should be charged if players are willing, as it shows respect and support for the creators. Otherwise, my world will lose a considerable number of creators, which is not conducive to the gaming environment.

    Taking Minecraft, a Chinese agency, as an example, mods can be charged and more creators will emerge. Since the creators' profit sharing has decreased, many top studios have announced their dissolution, resulting in the loss of a lot of content for the Chinese version of Minecraft! The extreme culture of free will bury many of the future of this game!

I love how every single one of the six people who said furniture should be in vanilla didn't give any reasons why.

This website however, amazingly gave us a reason for doing something (for once) by saying WHY they rejected furniture.

"Features that inhibit natural creativity or can already be done in other ways are not being considered."

Basically, if they added a chair to minecraft, or a table, it would deincentivise players to make their own chairs/tables. It would take away the aspect of creativity in minecraft, and for what? So you can easily get a table that would take 10 seconds to make on your own with a piston? Even if you're a terrible builder just look up chair build hacks or something.

Cars are even worse. People don't make cars on "a crafting table" and out of all seventeen of the minecraft updates, the most modern thing they made was a copper telescope. We already have horses to move around, and the only reasoning anyone seems to give for cars is "so i can use it in my modern world." Again, Mojang cannot add something that shows significant bias for or against a type of playing/building style, and adding cars would do both of these.

Mojang has rejected these ideas for a reason! The only rejected ideas that would actually add to this game (vertical slabs and ducks,) incidentally, HAVE NO REASONING AS TO WHY THEY WERE REJECTED! See a pattern? No Furniture, no cars, and definitely no guns!

Capes should be more common than they are now.

Ideally, any capes you own in Java could be used on Bedrock in the Dressing Room, or Bedrock's capes you own in Java's skin menu. It'd also be good if our capes from Minecraft Dungeons could be used in both Java and Bedrock (and Dungeons emotes in Bedrock since they even have duplicate emotes from Bedrock in Dungeons), think cape parity. This gives us more colors to pick from to match our skins (since we only have a gold and blue cape on Bedrock & the Red Migrator on Java for most recent players). It would also encourage players to play Mojang's other games to try earning the other capes.

Purchasable capes would also be nice from either promotional material (similar to the promo codes in cereal or with action figures), or on the marketplace on Bedrock. Skin pack exclusive capes should be usable on any skin (Jeb's Scarf cape in Skin pack 3).

They could also give out capes in Minecraft Now's/Minecon Live's Livestreams so any player tuning in or who attends can get it (not just attendees due to the pandemic and ticket scalpers). Scalpers have always been a issue with Minecon so giving everyone the cape who tunes in or shows up to the convention could fix it so only players who are passionate about the game and actually want to attend a convention can get tickets and go instead of just scalpers.

Capes have been the only way Java (which lacks Bedrocks level of customization) and in general players can customize in addition to their skin.

Capes never should have been as rare as they are and there should have been many free or purchasable capes and alternatives instead of only NFT-like, near impossible to get capes which are forever unobtainable.

The Vanilla cape is cross platform, all capes should have cape parity and be cross platform.

Capes need to be more inclusive and less exclusive.
